Preparation, basic properties and catalytic activity of Mg/La and Al/La catalysts for biodiesel production from refined and acid soybean oil Ricardo Santório Cláudia de Oliveira Veloso Cristiane A. Henriques ⁎ PPGEQ—Universidade do Estado do Rio de Janeiro, Rua São Francisco Xavier, 524, Maracanã, 20550-013 Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil PPGEQ—Universidade do Estado do Rio de Janeiro Rua São Francisco Xavier 524 Maracanã Rio de Janeiro RJ 20550-013 Brazil ⁎ Corresponding author. Fax: +55 2123340159. Graphical abstract The growing concern for environmental preservation combined with the possibility of depletion of energy obtained from fossil fuels has driven industry to develop alternative fuels from renewable resources and environmentally non-aggressive processes. Biodiesel is an important alternative fuel whose properties are similar to those of petrodiesel. Catalysts containing Mg/La (Mg/La molar ratio=9:1) were prepared by coprecipitation using three methods that differed according to precipitating agent, and calcination temperature. The catalyst prepared with (NH4)2CO3/NH4OH as precipitating agent and calcined at 450°C presented the best physicochemical and catalytic properties. Catalysts based on Mg/Al and Al/La with different chemical compositions were synthesized under the selected conditions. The catalytic behavior of these materials for transesterification of soybean oil with methanol was investigated and the catalysts with M/La molar ratio equal to 9:1 (M=Mg or Al) showed the best catalytic performance. Catalytic tests were also carried out in the presence of acid soybean oil. It was verified that the catalysts used have sites capable of catalyzing esterification and transesterification reactions. Keywords Biodiesel Mg/La catalysts Al/La catalysts Acid oils Acid–base properties 1 Introduction The energy consumed in the world is mostly produced from fossil resources. There are some important concerns about the use of these resources such as the decrease of their availability, and the potential environmental impacts of the gases produced by combustion of fossil fuels [1]. Thus, due to the growing need of fuels and the concern about the preservation of the environment, the research for renewable and cleaner fuels such as biodiesel has received significant attention. Biodiesel is a mixture of fatty acid esters derived from the transesterification of vegetable oils or animal fats with short-chain alcohols (methanol or ethanol). The transesterification reaction is carried out through acid or basic catalysis in homogeneous or heterogeneous medium. However, acid catalysts show lower activity than basic catalysts. The use of heterogeneous basic catalysts for biodiesel production is a promising cleaner and more selective alternative for conventional homogeneous process due to the following advantages: little or no corrosion, easy separation, easy handling and reusability, possible use of fixed bed reactors. The high cost of the refined raw materials may impair the future commercialization of biodiesel plants, since 70% of biodiesel production cost is related to refined oil [2]. As an alternative to overcome this problem, the use of cheaper raw materials such as unrefined oils and fats, oil resulting from domestic, commercial and industrial processing, as well as acid sludge originated during the refining of vegetable oils, seems to be a good option to reduce the overall cost of biodiesel production. The development of heterogeneous catalysts which are capable of catalyzing both the transesterification reaction of vegetable oils and the esterification reaction of free fatty acids in a single step is the focus of recent studies [3–6]. Mixed oxides with acid and/or basic properties are widely used for biodiesel production [7]. In addition to their relatively low cost, another important aspect of these materials is the possibility of adjusting their acid–base properties so that the presence of water or free fatty acids in the reaction medium did not adversely affect the transesterification yield. Coprecipitation is a widely used synthesis method, in which a basic solution is used as the precipitating agent, for these materials. Typically, a Na2CO3/NaOH solution is employed. However, there is controversy about its use, since one cannot rule out the presence of residual alkali metal in the catalyst, which can be leached into reaction medium promoting homogeneous catalysis and impairing the quality of the final product [8,9]. Thus, the replacement of Na2CO3/NaOH mixture by other precipitating agents intended to avoid the problem of the possible presence of alkaline contaminants in the final catalyst. This problem can be circumvented with the use of solutions free from alkali metals, for example, a mixture of (NH4)2CO3/NH4OH [9,10] or urea solutions [11,12]. Recently, the use of catalysts containing rare earth oxides for transesterification reactions has been reported such as La2O3/MgO [2,6,13–15], La2O3/ZnO [3,16], La2O3/Al2O3 [4,17,18], La2O3/CaO [19] and Eu2O3/Al2O3 [20]. Catalysts containing Mg–La [13,14], Mg–Al–La [2,14], Mg–La impregnated with potassium [6,15] were used to produce biodiesel from different refined and acid vegetable oils. Desmartin-Chomel et al. [14] investigated the catalytic properties of MgLa and MgLaAl mixed oxides in the transesterification of soybean oil with methanol or ethanol. The catalysts were prepared by coprecipitation using KOH/K2CO3 as precipitating agent. The catalysts showed a low incorporation of lanthanum. The sample with an Mg/La molar ratio equal to 3 showed the highest basicity. According to the authors, the solids retained small amounts of potassium in their structure even after washing; however, the contribution of potassium to the amount of basic sites was small. The reactions were performed at 65°C with methanol (methanol/oil molar ratio=6) and 80°C with ethanol (ethanol/oil molar ratio=58) using 0.5g of catalyst activated at 500°C. The esters yield reached after 5h was 58 and 60% with ethanol and methanol, respectively. Additionally, no leaching of Mg and La to reaction medium was observed. The catalytic activity of basic Mg and La compounds for the transesterification of refined sunflower oil with methanol was studied [13]. Catalysts with different Mg/La weight ratios (1:1, 2:1, 3:1) were prepared by coprecipitation using KOH/K2CO3 as precipitating agent. The increase in magnesium content resulted in the decrease of specific area, the increase of the overall density of basic sites, and the increase in catalytic activity for the studied reaction. The sample with the highest content of Mg (ML-3) showed 100% of methyl esters yield after 20min at 65°C using a methanol/oil molar ratio of 53 and 0.05g of catalyst calcined at 650°C. This catalyst was reused five times with a variation of 5% in the conversion obtained in each cycle. The influence of the presence of water and free fatty acids (palmitic acid) in the vegetable oil in the catalytic performance of ML-3 sample was investigated using a model feedstock. The authors observed that this catalyst in the presence of 10% of water in sunflower oil showed 100% conversion of oil. Concerning the presence of free fatty acid (palmitic acid), ML-3 sample showed a slightly lower activity for transesterification for concentrations from 1 to 5% of fatty acid. A model feedstock containing sunflower oil, palmitic acid (5%) and water (5%) was tested with ML-3 catalyst that was able to convert 100% of the vegetable oil after 4h. Al,La-materials are slightly used as catalysts for biodiesel synthesis. The examples depicted from the literature show the application of La2O3 supported on Al2O3 for transesterification reactions. Endalew et al. [4] studied heterogeneous catalysts for biodiesel production from Jatropha curcas oil with high content of free fatty acids (17mg KOHg−1 or 9% free fatty acid). The materials tested for the simultaneous esterification and transesterification reactions were CaO, Li/CaO, La2O3/ZnO, ZnO, La2O3/Al2O3, Al2O3 and La0,1Ca0,9MnO3. The La2O3/ZnO catalyst showed the highest activity (30.1% conversion to biodiesel at 60°C with a methanol/oil ratio=6). Lanthanum oxide supported on alumina (La2O3/Al2O3) prepared by impregnation was also tested for the transesterification of J. curcas oil at 60°C for 3h using alcohol/oil molar ratio of 6 and 5% of catalyst (based on oil amount) and a conversion of 11.9% was achieved. The low activity can be related to the small pore diameter of the catalyst that can cause diffusional limitations. Russbueldt and Hoelderich evaluated the activity of different bulk and supported rare earth oxides for the transesterification palm (refined and raw) or rapeseed oil with methanol [18]. The reaction was studied under autogenous pressure, employing temperatures in the range of 150–250°C, methanol/oil molar ratio ranging from 7 to 28 and catalyst concentration of 10wt.%. The bulk oxides were compared at 200°C using a methanol/oil molar ratio of 28, and La2O3 was the most active. When this catalyst was used with refined palm oil, esters and glycerol yields were equal to 90.6% and 84.7%, respectively, while in the case of crude oil, the yields were equal to 97.2% (ester) and 94.2% (glycerol). It was also observed that the catalytic activity of rare earth oxides decreased with decreasing cationic radius that is directly related to the decrease in basicity. The activity of rare earth oxides (10wt.%) supported on γ-Al2O3 was compared for the transesterification of rapeseed oil at 200°C using a methanol/oil molar ratio of 28. The incorporation of the rare earth oxide on the support led to the formation of superficial aluminate species, whose catalytic activity was less than that of the corresponding bulk oxides. Specifically for La2O3/Al2O3, methyl esters yield was about 50%. The catalyst containing 20wt.% of La2O3 on Al2O3 showed the best performance with a methyl esters yield equal to 60.2%. The authors highlighted the importance of the amount of active phase and the accessibility to surface active sites, because a maximum for catalytic activity was observed when La2O3 content was varied. In this work, the transesterification of soybean oil with methanol was studied in the presence of Mg, La- and Al, La-solid catalysts with different acid–base properties. The catalysts were characterized according to their physicochemical properties, in order to correlate them with their catalytic behavior. The catalysts with Mg/La molar ratio of 9:1 were prepared through three different methods using urea, NaOH/Na2CO3, and (NH4)2CO3/NH4OH as precipitating agents. The influence of the calcination temperature of the precursor was also studied. The possible leaching of basic species and/or metal ions into the reaction medium was evaluated. The influence of the chemical composition of La catalysts in their physicochemical and catalytic properties was studied. Two series of catalysts (Mg/La and Al/La) were prepared with M/La (M=Mg or La) molar ratio varying in three levels 1:9; 1:1 and 9:1. Finally, selected catalysts were evaluated in the simultaneous transesterification and esterification of an acid soybean oil (model feedstock containing 10wt.% oleic acid) with methanol, in order to investigate their potential use in the transesterification of low cost feedstock. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Precursors The influence of precipitating agent in catalyst physicochemical properties was investigated for Mg, La-catalysts with a Mg/La molar ratio equal to 9:1. The precursor materials were synthesized by coprecipitation, at room temperature, using an aqueous solution of metallic cations (solution A) and a highly basic solution (solution B), under vigorous stirring. Solution A, contained Mg(NO3)2·4H2O and La(NO3)3·9H2O dissolved in distilled water with 1.5molL−1 in (Mg+La) for methods 1 and 2, and 1.4molL−1 for method 3. Solution B contained the precipitating agent such as solutions of urea (method 1), Na2CO3/NaOH (method 2), and (NH4)2CO3/NH4OH (method 3) at appropriated concentrations. Method 1 was adapted from Yan et al. [3]. A 1.5molL−1 urea solution (solution B) was placed in a 250mL PTFE reactor and solution A was slowly dropped (60mLh−1) under vigorous stirring to solution B. When the addition is finished, the gel formed was vigorous stirred for 4h. Then, the gel was aged under constant pH (13) for 18h at 60°C. Afterwards, the solid obtained was filtrated and washed with hot distilled water until neutral pH and dried at 80°C overnight. Method 2 was based on the literature [21–23]. Solution B was prepared dissolving appropriate amounts of Na2CO3 and NaOH in distilled water in order to obtain a carbonate (CO3 2−) concentration equal to 1.0molL−1 and proper loading of NaOH to maintain gel aging pH equal to 10. This solution was added to a 250mL PTFE reactor and solution A was slowly dropped to solution B (60mLh−1) under vigorous stirring. When the addition is finished, the solution formed was vigorous stirred for 4h. The crystallization step was carried out under constant pH (10) for 18h at 60°C. Afterwards, the solid obtained was filtrated, washed with hot distilled water until neutral pH and dried at 100°C overnight. Method 3 was based on Chuayplod and Trakarnpruk experimental procedure [2], 90mL of solution A with 1.4molL−1 of cations were slowly added (60mLh−1) to 120mL of a 0.94molL−1 solution of (NH4)2CO3 (solution B) under stirring at 65°C for 3h, and pH (11) was maintained constant by adding NH4OH. Then, the solid obtained was filtrated, washed with hot distilled water until neutral pH, and dried at 100°C overnight. 2.1.2 Thermal treatment of the precursors The mixed oxides were obtained by calcining the precursors using two methods. In the first procedure, the precursors were calcined under dry air (50mLmin−1) from room temperature to 450°C, at a 5°Cmin−1 heating rate, and kept at this temperature for 8h, steps of 1h at 150 and 300°C were done. In the second procedure, the precursors were calcined at 750°C for 2h under static atmosphere in a muffle. The catalysts were named Mg/La 9:1 (X)–T, where X is the synthesis method number (1, 2, or 3) and T is the calcination temperature. 2.1.3 Synthesis of catalysts with different chemical composition Method 3 and calcination temperature of 450°C were chosen as the best conditions to synthesize Mg/La catalysts. These conditions were used to prepare Mg/La and Al/La materials with different chemical composition. So, for Mg/La and Al/La samples, solution A was prepared using nitrates solutions so that cations concentration was 1.4molL−1 and Mg or Al/La molar ratio was 9:1, 1:1 and 1:9. The mixed oxides were obtained by calcining the precursors at 450°C. The catalysts were named Mg/La Y and Al/La Y, where Y is nominal molar ratio between cations (1:9; 1:1; 9:1). 2.2 Physicochemical characterization The bulk chemical composition of the samples was determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP/IOS) using a Thermo Scientific Spectrometer, ICAP 6000 Series. The emission lines monitored were 309.3nm for Al, 279.6nm for Mg, and 412.3nm for La. 50mg of Mg/La samples were dissolved in 8mL of concentrated nitric acid (HNO3). For Al/La samples, 8mL of chloridric acid (HCl), 3mL nitric acid (HNO3) and 2mL of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) were used to solubilize the sample. The dissolution process was carried out at 80°C for 1h. X-ray powder diffractograms were recorded in a Rigaku Miniflex X-Ray Diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator using Cu Kα radiation, 30kV and 15mA, in order to determine the crystalline phases present in the samples. The identification of the phases were done using MDI Jade software (Materials Data Inc.) and the International Centre for Diffraction Data (ICDD) PDF-2 database. Textural characteristics such as specific surface area (BET method), microporous volume (t-plot method), and mesoporous volume (BJH method) were determined by N2 adsorption–desorption at −196°C in a Micromeritics ASAP (Accelerated Surface Area and Porosity) model 2020. Before analysis, the samples were pretreated under vacuum overnight at 450°C. Superficial chemical composition was determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The analysis were performed in a surface analysis station that operates under ultra high vacuum (UHV), using an electron spectrometer equipped with a hemispherical analyzer PHOIBOS 150, an X-ray cannon XR-50 of double anode using Al Kα non-monochromatic radiation (1486.6eV). The anode was operated at 10kV and 10mA. General spectra and high resolution spectra were recorded with pass energy of 50 and 20eV, respectively. The C1s binding energy at 284.8eV was used as an internal reference for correcting the binding energy displacement that occurs due to surface charges. The spectra were corrected by subtracting the background using the Shirley method, and adjusted using CasaXPS software version 2.3.14. The compositions were calculated using Al 2p and La 3d core levels. The samples were analyzed after heating at 450°C. The sample went through chambers under successively growing vacuum: pre-chamber (10−3 mbar), intermediate chamber (10−6–10−9 mbar) and UHV chamber (<3×10−9 mbar). During analysis, the pressure in UHV chamber was maintained in the range 5×10−10 and 1×10−9 mbar. 2.3 Leaching of basic species and metallic ions The leaching of basic species was evaluated using the methodology described in the literature by different authors [8,24–26]. Water was chosen as leaching agent due to its high polarity and easy handling. In a typical procedure, 250mg of sample were suspended in 25mL of water and the system was stirred for 1h at room temperature; then it was filtrated. 2.5mL of 1% phenolphthalein solution in methanol were added to filtrate, which was then titrated with benzoic acid diluted in methanol (0.01molL−1). The leaching of metallic ions was also investigated in the filtrate. Mg and La leaching was determined by ICP/OES. The emission lines 279.6 and 412.3nm were monitored for Mg and La, respectively. Na leaching was measured by flame atomic absorption spectrometry using a Perkin Elmer AAnalyst300 spectrometer. These measurements were performed using the absorption line at 589nm (Na). 2.4 Basicity characterization 2.4.1 Temperature programmed desorption of CO2 (TPD-CO2) The strength distribution and basic sites density were measured using temperature programmed desorption of CO2 in a unit equipped with thermal conductivity detector. The catalysts (200mg) were pretreated under a He flow (30mLmin−1), starting from room temperature up to 450°C at a heating rate of 1°Cmin−1, and then kept at this temperature for 10h. After thermal treatment, the catalysts were cooled down to 50°C and exposed to a gas mixture containing 4% CO2 in He (30mLmin−1). After adsorption, physically adsorbed CO2 was removed by passing a He flow (30mLmin−1) at 50°C. Aiming to measure the amount physically adsorbed CO2, another adsorption step with CO2/He mixture was carried out followed by another desorption step under He. Then, desorption profile of chemisorbed CO2 was obtained by heating the sample from 50 to 450°C under He (30mLmin−1) using a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1. The amount of chemically adsorbed CO2 was calculated as the difference between the total and the physically adsorbed amounts. 2.4.2 2-Propanol transformation 2-Propanol transformation was used to measure acid/base sites density and acid/base sites type on the synthesized materials. This reaction was carried out in vapor phase at atmospheric pressure. 2-propanol was fed to the reactor through a saturator held at 20°C using N2 as carrier gas. Samples were thermal treated in situ from room temperature up to 450°C, using a heating rate of 1°Cmin−1, and then kept at this temperature for 10h. The reaction temperature was 350°C, N2/2-propanol molar ratio was equal to 23, and weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) was 13.0g2-propanol gcatalyst −1 h−1. The reaction products were analyzed by on-line gas chromatography using a VARIAN CP 3800 gas chromatograph, equipped with a capillary column PORAPLOT Q-HT and a flame ionization detector. 2.4.3 Titration using Hammett indicators The basic sites strength was qualitatively determined by Hammett indicators, according to the methodology described by Fraile et al. [25]. 25mg of catalyst were added to 1.0mL of a 0.1% indicator solution in methanol, the mixture was stirred and then allowed to stand for 1h. After that the color of the solid was observed. Neutral red (pK a =6.8), bromothymol blue (pK a =7.2), phenolphthalein (pK a =9.3) and 4-nitroaniline (pK a =18.4) were used as Hammett indicators. The quantitative determination of the solid basicity was measured by titration with benzoic acid according to the methodology also described by Fraile et al. [25]. A suspension containing 15mg of catalyst and 2mL of a 0.1mgmL−1 Hammett indicator solution in toluene was stirred for 30min and then titrated with a 0.01molL−1 solution of benzoic acid until the color of the indicator changes. The same Hammett indicators used for qualitative determination were employed for the measurement of the basic site density. 2.5 Catalytic performance 2.5.1 Tests using edible soybean oil The transesterification reaction of soybean oil with methanol was carried out in liquid phase, under autogenous pressure using a 50mL stainless steel batch Parr reactor model 4843. Immediately before the runs, the catalysts were calcined using appropriated procedure in order to obtain mixed oxides. After activation, they were rapidly transferred to the reactor containing the mixture of soybean oil and methanol. Then, the system was heated to reaction temperature. The catalytic performance of the different catalysts was evaluated at the following reaction conditions: reaction temperature=130 and 200°C; methanol/soybean oil molar ratio=45; reaction time=4h; 5wt.% of catalyst (referred to the amount of soybean oil, which molar weight is 850gmol−1); stirring=500rpm. At the end of each test, the system was rapidly cooled down to room temperature and the catalyst was separated by centrifugation. The lower density phase, which contains the methyl ester mixture, was removed and after methanol elimination it was analyzed by gas chromatography using a VARIAN 3800 chromatograph equipped with a 30m Carbowax 20M capillary column and a flame ionization detector. The main products were methyl esters of palmitic (C16), stearic (C18), oleic (C18:1) and linoleic (C18:2) acids. Methyl heptadecanoate was used as internal standard for the determination of fatty acid methyl esters (FAME) yield that is expressed in terms of weight percentage, as described in the European Norm EN14103. 2.5.2 Tests using a model acid soybean oil The model acid soybean oil was composed by 10wt.% oleic acid in edible soybean oil. The catalytic tests were carried out at the same experimental conditions used for edible soybean oil. FAME yield was determined by gas chromatography and oleic acid conversion was measured by titration using a NaOH solution (0.04molL−1) and a Metler DL 25 automatic titrator. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The influence of preparation method The influence of preparation method on physicochemical properties and catalytic performance of Mg, La-based catalysts with a nominal Mg/La molar ratio of 9:1 was studied. Three coprecipitation methods that use different precipitating agents: (1) urea, (2) Na2CO3/NaOH and (3) (NH4)2CO3/NH4OH were investigated. The calcination temperature effects on the properties of the catalysts were also studied. 3.1.1 Physicochemical properties The X-ray diffractograms of Mg/La 9:1 samples calcined at 450 and 750°C are shown in Fig. 1 . For the samples synthesized by methods 1 and 2, the thermal treatment at 450°C led to the formation of two crystalline phases of lanthanum carbonate, La2CO5 (JPCDS 23-0320) and La2O2CO3 (JPCDS 48-1113), coexisting with MgO-periclase phase (JPCDS 45-0946). For Mg/La 9:1 (3) sample, the formation of crystalline phases of MgO-periclase (JPCDS 45-0946) and La2O2CO3 (JPCDS 48-1113) was observed. These results indicate that the lower calcination temperature, 450°C, was not high enough to completely decompose lanthanum phases, so that the formation of lanthanum oxide was not observed at this temperature. Fraile et al. reported a similar behavior for samples containing lanthanum and calcined at 500°C [8]. For the samples calcined at 750°C, regardless of preparation method, La2O3 (JPCDS 05-0602) and MgO-periclase (JPCDS 45-0946) phases were identified, indicating that, at 750°C, the lanthanum carbonate phases were completely decomposed to oxide phase. Babu et al. [13] and Desmatin-Chomel et al. [14] reported similar results for Mg/La samples calcined at 650°C, although the latter have only reported the formation of La2O3. The decomposition of lanthanum carbonate species only occurs at temperatures above 600°C, leading to materials with good crystallinity in which MgO and La2O3 phases coexist [8]. Concerning the chemical composition of the samples (Table 1 ), it was verified that, regardless of the precipitating agent, the Mg/La molar ratio of the samples was lower than the nominal molar ratio of the synthesis gels, indicating a lower Mg incorporation. Similar trends have been reported in the literature for Mg–La and La–Mg–Al catalysts prepared by coprecipitation [2,14,27,28]. The specific surface area and mesoporous volume were determined using N2 physisorption at −196°C and are shown in Table 1. The increase of calcination temperature to 750°C, regardless of preparation method, caused a large reduction in specific surface area, which varied in the range of 20–50m2 g−1. The specific surface area decrease is consistent with those reported in the literature [13,14] for Mg, La-catalysts calcined at 650°C. The mesoporous volume of Mg/La 9:1 (2)-750 and Mg/La 9:1 (3)-750 samples decreased, while for Mg/La 9:1 (1)-750 sample it was not affected by calcination temperature. No micropores were identified for all samples. The leaching of metal ions (Mg2+, La3+ and Na+), which could contaminate biodiesel, and basic species, whose presence in the reaction medium could promote the transesterification reaction through a homogeneous process, was verified. Table 1 shows the amount of leached Mg and Na. La leaching was not observed. For samples prepared using method 2, regardless of the calcination temperature, Na leaching was high, indicating that this element remained occluded in the catalyst even after washing. Several authors have already mentioned the presence of alkali metal ions after thorough washing during preparation step [8,14]. Mg leaching was higher for samples calcined at 750°C. Leaching of basic species into reaction medium was also evaluated and the results are presented in Table 1. Only the sample synthesized with (NH4)2CO3/NH4OH and calcined at 450°C showed no basic species leaching. The amount and strength of basic sites are important characteristics of basic solid catalysts and their measurement is essential for understanding the catalytic performance of these materials. In the present study, the following techniques were used: titration with Hammett indicators, 2-propanol transformation, and temperature programmed desorption of CO2. For all catalysts, a color change of the following indicators was observed: neutral red (pKa=6.8), bromothymol blue (pKa=7.2) and phenolphthalein (pKa=9.3), but no color change was noticed when 4-nitroaniline indicator (pKa=18.4) was used. Therefore, it can be concluded that the strength of the basic sites present on the samples are distributed over a wide range, which can be represented as follows 18.4>H_>6.8, where H_ is the site strength. The amount of basic sites present on the catalysts was measured by titration with benzoic acid using phenolphthalein as indicator. Fig. 2 shows the basicity expressed in mmol of basic sites capable of changing the color of phenolphthalein per gram of catalyst, that is, sites with strength greater than 9.3. Regardless of preparation method, the increase of calcination temperature decreased basic sites density. For samples calcined at 450°C, the higher amount of basic sites was observed for samples prepared through methods 1 and 3. The sample prepared by method 3 showed the highest concentration of basic sites among the samples calcined at 750°C. Although titration methods using Hammett indicators have been used in recent studies to determine the basic properties of porous solids [8,26,29,30], it is important to note that this technique remains controversial since the results can be affected by solvent-support interactions [31] and by the accessibility of the probe molecule into the pores [32]. The catalytic performance of the samples was compared for the transesterification of soybean oil with methanol at 200°C using a methanol/oil molar ratio equal to 45 and 5wt.% of catalyst during 4h. The results expressed as fatty acid methyl esters (FAME) yield are shown in Fig. 3 . The authors had previously observed that no methyl esters were formed when the transesterification of soybean oil and methanol was performed in the absence of catalyst [23]. As shown in Fig. 3, all catalysts were active for the transesterification of soybean oil with methanol. For samples calcined at 450°C, FAME yields were found in the range of 60–81%, with the highest values observed for the catalysts prepared by methods 1 and 3. For catalysts calcined at 750°C, a slight increase of FAME yield was observed among the three catalysts prepared using different precipitating agents. For the catalysts prepared by method 2, the calcination temperature did not affect biodiesel yield, while for Mg/La 9:1 (1) and Mg/La 9:1 (3) samples a significant reduction was observed. Regardless of calcination temperature, Mg/La 9:1 (3) sample was more active and showed the highest concentration of basic sites (Fig. 2) and specific area (Table 1). FAME yield showed a good correlation with the amount of basic sites measured by titration with benzoic acid using phenolphthalein as indicator, except for the sample prepared by method 2 and calcined at 450°C, which showed low yield despite of a high amount of basic sites when compared with the samples calcined at 750°C. Taking into account that the increase of calcination temperature caused a decrease of specific area, it can be highlighted that lanthanum oxide carbonate crystalline phases, La2CO5 and La2O2CO3 are more active than lanthanum oxide, La2O3, for the transesterification of soybean oil with methanol for Mg, La-mixed oxides. According to the previous results, method 3, which used (NH4)2CO3/NH4OH solution as precipitating agent, and the calcination temperature of 450°C were chosen as the most promising synthesis conditions, because the sample prepared by this method showed high catalytic activity. Furthermore, for this sample, no leaching of basic species titratable by benzoic acid was observed and the amount of magnesium solubilized into reaction medium can be considered negligible. Generally, catalysts calcined at 750°C showed low specific area, mesoporous volume and basic site concentration, justifying the choice of the lower (450°C) calcination temperature. The presence of Na species occluded in the catalyst that can be leached into the reaction medium was confirmed for samples prepared by method 2 (using Na2CO3/NaOH as precipitating agent), as mentioned in the literature [8–10]. 3.2 The influence of the chemical composition of the catalysts Two series of catalysts, Mg/La and Al/La, were prepared with M/La (M=Mg or Al) molar ratio varying in three levels 1:9, 1:1 and 9:1. The catalytic performance of these materials was evaluated in the transesterification of soybean oil and methanol at different temperatures. 3.2.1 Mg, La-catalysts The X-ray diffractograms of the samples calcined at 450°C are presented in Fig. 4 . The Mg/La 1:9 sample showed high crystallinity, and the presence of La2CO5 (JPCDS 23-0320) and La2O2CO3 (JPCDS 48-1113) phases was identified. In the case of Mg/La 9:1 sample, the presence of La2O2CO3 (JPCDS 48-1113) and MgO-periclase (JPCDS 45-0946) phases was observed with low crystallinity, while Mg/La 1:1 sample showed peaks with very low intensity indicating that it is an amorphous material. Table 2 shows Mg/La molar ratio of the synthesis gel and solid samples. As previously noted for Mg/La samples prepared by different methods, the Mg/La molar ratio of synthesized samples was lower than that of synthesis gel for all studied compositions, confirming the low incorporation of Mg. This effect was more significant for the sample with the highest La content (Mg/La 1:9). Lanthanum content increase caused a significant decrease in specific area and pore volume for Mg,La-catalysts, so that Mg/La 1:9 sample showed characteristics of a non-porous solid. The same behavior was mentioned in the literature for Mg/La catalysts prepared by coprecipitation and calcined at 650°C [14]. No leaching of basic species titratable by benzoic acid in the presence of phenolphthalein as indicator was observed, except for Mg/La 1:1 sample that showed a small amount of leached basic species (Table 2). Therefore, it can be considered that, for this series of catalysts, the contribution of homogeneous catalysis can be neglected in the study of transesterification of soybean oil with methanol. The density of basic sites was measured by titration with benzoic acid using different indicators. The highest density of basic sites was noted for Mg/La 9:1 sample and La content increase causes a decrease in basic sites density (Fig. 5 ). Mg/La 9:1 and Mg/La 1:1 samples presented basic sites strength in the range 18.4>H _ >6.8. The strength distribution and density of basic sites on Mg/La catalysts were also determined by temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 and the results are presented in Table 2. It can be seen that Mg/La 9:1 and Mg/La 1:1 samples have similar basic sites density that is much higher than that of Mg/La 1:9. This trend is similar to that observed for basic site density measured by titration using neutral red and phenolphthalein as indicators (sites with H_ greater than 7.2 and 9.2, respectively). The TPD-CO2 profiles of Mg/La samples are shown in Fig. 6 and their complexity suggests a broad distribution of basic sites strength for all catalysts. The basicity of Mg/Al mixed oxides derived from hydrotalcites and of different MgO samples was characterized by TPD-CO2, the presence of desorption peaks around 100°C could be attributed to an interaction of CO2 with weak basic sites, basic sites with intermediate strength were responsible for the peaks observed at temperatures around 200°C, desorption peaks in the range of 250–300°C are related to strong basic sites, while the desorption of CO2 at temperatures above 400°C indicates the presence of very strong basic sites (superbasic sites) [33]. The three Mg/La samples showed different strength profiles. Mg/La 1:1 and Mg/La 1:9 samples presented mainly superbasic sites and strong sites, respectively. On the other hand, a wide distribution of basic sites was observed for Mg/La 9:1 sample. Mg,La-catalysts with different chemical compositions were active for 2-propanol transformation (Fig. A1 in Supplementary data). Acetone and propene were formed with different distributions according to Mg/La molar ratio. Mg/La 9:1 catalyst was able to completely convert 2-propanol under the studied conditions, whereas Mg/La 1:1 and Mg/La 1:9 samples exhibited lower conversions (less than 40%). From these results we can infer the following sequence for the amount of acid-basic sites capable of converting 2-propanol: Mg/La 9:1>Mg/La 1:1>Mg/La 1:9. For all catalysts of Mg/La series, propene was the main product formed from 2-propanol. The formation of propene via 2-propanol dehydration can occur through E2 mechanism that involves Lewis acid sites and basic sites, both with intermediate or strong strength, and also through E1b mechanism in which an intermediate carbanion is formed on strong basic sites associated to weak Lewis acid sites [34]. The interpretation of the results should be done carefully, since E1b mechanism is also responsible for the dehydrogenation reaction that forms acetone, which occurs through the same carbanion intermediate [34]. Thus, the formation of propene indicates the presence of acidic and basic sites in these samples. On the other hand, the small amount of acetone confirms the presence of strong basic sites as this product is formed by the dehydrogenation reaction that occurs on strong basic catalysts via E1b mechanism. On a general overview, the three techniques used to characterize the basicity of the samples (titration with benzoic acid, TPD-CO2, and 2-propanol transformation) indicated that Mg/La 1:9 sample present the lowest amount of basic sites as well as the lowest strength. On the other hand, Mg/La 9:1 and Mg/La 1:1 samples are similar in density and strength of the basic sites, except for 2-propanol transformation. The influence of the chemical composition of Mg/La samples on their catalytic performance in the transesterification of soybean oil with methanol was evaluated at two reaction temperatures 130 and 200°C. The other experimental conditions were: catalyst concentration=5wt.% (based on oil amount), methanol/oil molar ratio=45, and time on stream=4h. FAME yields are shown in Fig. 7 . As can be seen, all catalysts were active for the transesterification of soybean oil with methanol. As expected, the increase in reaction temperature caused an increase in FAME yield for all samples. At 200°C, no significant differences were observed in FAME yield for Mg,La-catalysts, suggesting a leveling-off effect of the catalytic performance of the solids. In order to establish the effect of chemical composition on the catalytic performance, a lower reaction temperature was used (130°C). At this temperature, chemical composition significantly affected FAME yield and the lowest FAME yield was verified for Mg/La 1:9 sample. The behavior of this sample compared to that with higher magnesium content (Mg/La 9:1) is consistent with the lower density of basic sites measured by the various techniques used in this study (titration with benzoic acid, TPD-CO2 and 2-propanol transformation) and also with the smaller specific area of this sample. The catalytic behavior of Mg/La samples is better correlated to TPD-CO2 basicity measurement, that is, the highest FAME yields obtained with Mg/La 9:1 and Mg/La 1:1 samples are related to basic site density and the presence of superbasic sites. On the other side, Mg/La 1:9 sample presents the lowest FAME yield and basic site density and also the absence of superbasic sites. A comparison of the results obtained in this study with those reported in the literature for similar materials is difficult, because there are several differences in experimental conditions of the catalytic tests and also in catalyst preparation that directly influence the active phases. Desmartin-Chomel et al. [14] tested Mg,La-based catalysts with a nominal Mg/La molar ratio of 2 and calcined at 500°C in the transesterification of soybean oil with methanol at 65°C using a methanol/oil molar ratio equal to 6 and a yield of 60% was achieved. Biodiesel yields obtained in the present study at a higher reaction temperature and methanol/oil molar ratio were equivalent to those reported by Desmartin-Chomel et al. [14]. It is important to highlight that the catalyst synthesized by Desmartin-Chomel et al. [14] showed K residue as a solution of KOH/K2CO3 was used as precipitating agent and no measure of leached basic species was done. Mg,La-catalysts with different Mg/La weight ratios (1:1, 2:1, 3:1) calcined at 650°C for the transesterification of vegetable oils with methanol were studied [13]. The sample with Mg/La weight ratio of 3:1 (Mg/La-3) showed high transesterification activity. They found a FAME yield of 97% at 65°C using a methanol/oil molar ratio equal to 53 and 5wt.% of catalyst for the most active Mg/La-catalyst. The activity of this material was attributed to the presence of strong basic sites assigned as lanthanum hydroxycarbonates. The catalysts synthesized in the present study showed much lower FAME yields than that reported by Babu et al. [13]. Four points have to be considered in this comparison: precipitating agent, leaching of K and basic species, Mg content, and methanol oil molar ratio. Babu et al. [13] synthesized their catalysts using KOH/K2CO3 as precipitating agent that could result in K residue on the catalyst and also K leaching to reaction medium. However, the authors did not measure K nor basic species leaching. Furthermore, it is important to observe that the Mg content of Mg/La-3 catalyst (Mg/La molar ratio of 17) and methanol/oil molar ratio are higher than those used in the present work. 3.2.2 Al,La-catalysts The X-ray diffractograms of Al/La compounds calcined at 450°C are presented in Fig. 8 . The profiles of Al/La 1:9 and Al/La 1:1 samples showed characteristic peaks of lanthanum oxycarbonates, La2CO5 (JCPDS 23-0320) and La2O2CO3 (JCPDS 48-1113), respectively. These results suggest that the calcination temperature used (450°C) was not sufficient for the decomposition of the precursors into La2O3. For the sample with the lowest content of La, no peaks were identified, indicating the formation of an amorphous material. The absence of peaks related to La phases for samples with less than 15% of La was reported in the literature for La2O3 supported on Al2O3 [35,36] or SiO2 [36,37] prepared by impregnation. No aluminum phase was observed probably aluminum oxides are perfectly dispersed in lanthanum oxycarbonates matrix as noticed for other mixed phase solids [21,22]. The major textural characteristics of Al, La-catalysts are given in Table 3 . As for Mg,La-catalysts, the increase of lanthanum content resulted in a significant decrease in specific area and pore volume of Al, La-catalysts, so that Al/La 1:9 sample presented characteristics of a non-porous solid. Similar trends have been reported in the literature for materials in which La was incorporated to Al2O3 by impregnation [35,36]. The comparison between the Al/La molar ratio of the synthesis gel and of the synthesized samples is shown in Table 3. It is observed that the chemical composition of Al, La-catalysts is consistent with the corresponding synthesis gel, suggesting that La and Al precipitation was complete. The chemical composition of the surface of Al/La 9:1 and Al/La 1:9 catalysts was measured using XPS and the results are shown in Table 3. The surface and bulk chemical compositions are significantly different. The surface chemical composition depends on Al/La molar ratio. For higher Al/La molar ratio, La concentration is higher, and for lower Al/La molar ratio, Al concentration is higher. Hence, the higher the lanthanum content is, the lower is the concentration of this element on surface so that aluminum presence predominates. Fig. 9 shows the spectra for Al 2p (A), La 3d (B), C 1s (C) and O 1s (D) for Al/La 9:1 sample. The Al 2p and O 1s spectra showed a unique and wide peak indicating the presence of a single chemical environment. The binding energy for Al 2p is similar to that found in the literature for aluminum oxide [38]. The peak at 531.3eV for O 1s can be associated with contributions from different species such as carbonates and hydroxides [39,40]. The C 1s spectrum shows two peaks at 289.6 and 284.6eV that can be associated to carbonate species [39] and to casually species present in the sample or in the analysis system [38], respectively. The presence of carbonate species on Al/La 9:1 sample was not observed by X-ray diffraction due to its amorphous characteristic, but these species are present on the surface of this material. Fig. 9 shows a typical spectrum for La 3d with well defined doublets showing the satellite structure which appears at the highest binding energy for 3d5/2 (835.1eV) and 3d3/2 (851.9eV) peaks [41]. For a La2O3 supported on Al2O3 sample, Alvero et al. [42] observed the La 3d5/2 binding energy at 835.5eV and they attributed this energy to La3+ ions poorly coordinated. No crystalline phases were observed for Al/La 9:1 sample; however, XPS analysis indicated the presence of lanthanum species and aluminum oxide on the surface. Carbonate and hydroxides species are also present on this sample. The spectra for Al 2p (A), La 3d (B), C 1s (C) and O 1s (D) for Al/La 1:9 sample are depicted in Fig. 10 . The spectrum corresponding to Al 2p has a unique and wide peak indicating the presence of a single chemical environment with a binding energy similar to that found in the literature for aluminum oxide [38]. In O 1s spectrum, there is a broad peak with maximum at 531.2eV and also a small shoulder at approximately 528.0eV. This suggests two chemical environments for this element. As seen for Al/La 9:1 sample, the peak at 531.2eV can be associated to contributions from different species such as carbonates and hydroxides. The shoulder at 528.0eV is related to oxide ions of the crystal lattice [40]. For C 1s spectrum, peaks at 289.5 and 284.6eV were identified and associated to carbonate species [39] and to species casually present in the sample or in the analysis system [38], respectively. In the case of Al/La 1:9 sample, the presence of carbonate species already observed using X-ray diffraction was confirmed. La 3d spectrum for Al/La 1:9 sample shows the characteristic doublets of this element with 3d5/2 (834.2eV) and 3d3/2 (851.0eV) peaks. Boukha et al. [43] observed for La2O3 supported on Al2O3 samples and calcined at different temperatures that the binding energy for La 3d5/2 was 834.5eV, but no clear assignments for the present species were made. Although the bulk and surface chemical composition of Al/La 9:1 and 1:9 samples are different, the nature of the surface species, carbonate, oxide and hydroxides species, is very similar. The presence of alumina on the surface was verified, even though this phase was not observed by X-ray diffraction. In order to identify the influence of the chemical composition in the chemical environment of each element, the binding energies observed for Al/La 9:1 and Al/La 1:9 samples shown in Figs. 9 and 10 were compared. It can be concluded that the chemical composition did not influence the binding energy of the studied elements. The only difference noticed between the samples was for O 1s where the appearance of a shoulder at 528.0eV indicates the presence of oxygen atoms associated to carbonate species and oxide ions on Al/La 1:9 sample. For Al/La catalysts, no leaching of basic species titratable with benzoic acid in the presence of phenolphthalein was observed thus suggesting that the contribution of the reaction in homogeneous medium can be neglected in the study of transesterification of soybean oil with methanol catalyzed by these materials. The density of basic sites was measured by titration with benzoic acid using different indicators. It is observed in Fig. 11 that Al/La 9:1 sample has the highest density of basic sites compared to the other catalysts and that the increase in La content resulted in a large decrease in basic sites concentration. Al/La 9:1 presented basic sites strength in the range 18.4>H_>6.8. According to this technique, the density of basic sites of Al/La 1:1 and Al/La 1:9 samples is very low. The strength distribution and density of basic sites on Al, La-catalysts were also determined by temperature-programmed desorption of CO2. The results for basic site density are illustrated in Table 3. It can be seen that Al/La 9:1 and Al/La 1:1 samples have similar density that are higher than that of Al/La 1:9 sample. This trend differs from that observed for basic site density measured by titration with Hammett indicators, where the amount of basic sites of Al/La 1:1 sample is much lower than that of Al/La 9:1. The TPD-CO2 profiles of Al/La samples are shown in Fig. 12 . For Al/La 9:1 sample, a single broad peak was observed which suggests the presence of basic sites that are strong enough to retain most of CO2 from 100 to 350°C. The TPD profile of Al/La 1:1 sample indicates the presence of sites with different basic strength. It is important to highlight the presence of strong sites that retain CO2 at 450°C. Al/La 1:9 sample also has a wide distribution of basic strength, most CO2 desorbed between 100 and 350°C. Al/La 9:1 and Al/La 1:9 samples present weak, intermediate and strong basic sites, while only Al/La 1:1 sample shows superbasic sites. Al,La-catalysts were active for 2-propanol conversion (Fig. A2 in Supplementary data). Acetone and propene were formed as products depending on the chemical composition of the catalysts. Al/La 9:1 and Al/La 1:1 catalysts completely converted 2-propanol, while Al/La 1:9 sample showed a lower conversion (about 30%). The larger amount of acid–basic sites capable of converting 2-propanol shown by Al/La 9:1 and Al/La 1:1 samples compared to Al/La 1:9 sample agrees with the trend of basic sites density established by TPD-CO2. For all Al/La samples, the major product was propene. Considering that the formation of this product may occur by different mechanisms involving acidic and basic sites (E2 and E1b mechanisms) [34], the formation of propene indicates the presence of both type of sites in Al/La samples. The presence of strong basic sites in these samples is inferred by the formation of acetone, which occurs through the E1b mechanism, involving the same intermediate carbanion associated with the formation of propene [34]. The conversion of 2-propanol producing simultaneously propene and acetone was observed for the reaction catalyzed by La2O3/Al2O3 [36], which was attributed to the presence of acid and basic sites. The influence of the chemical composition of Al, La-catalysts on the transesterification of soybean oil with methanol was studied at different temperatures (130 and 200°C) using a methanol/soybean oil molar ratio equal to 45 and 5wt.% of catalyst. The catalytic results expressed as FAME yield are depicted in Fig. 13 . As observed for Mg, La-catalysts, all the Al, La-catalysts were active for the transesterification of soybean oil with methanol. The increase in reaction temperature caused an increase in FAME yield for all samples, as expected. However, at 200°C, no significant difference in FAME yield was observed for Al, La-catalysts, indicating a leveling-off effect for the catalytic performance of the solids. So, the influence of chemical composition in catalytic performance was studied at 130°C. It was observed that the chemical composition affected FAME yield and a minimum for this parameter was verified for Al/La 1:1 sample. Attempts were made to establish a correlation between the catalytic performance of the samples and their physicochemical characteristics. However, neither the type of crystalline phases nor textural characteristics showed a correlation with catalytic activity. Although the techniques used to characterize basic properties have indicated the presence of strong basic sites on samples, it was not possible to correlate basicity measurements with catalytic performance, particularly when sample Al/La 1:1 was considered. This sample presented the lowest catalytic activity at 130°C but basic sites density (measured by TPD of CO2 and 2-propanol transformation) similar to that of Al/La 9:1 sample. The FAME yields obtained with Al, La-catalysts in this work can be considered promising when compared with those reported in the literature for materials containing La or Al oxides, which have been little explored in the production of biodiesel. Russbueldt and Hoelderich [18] evaluated the activity of different bulk rare earth oxides and also rare earth oxides supported on γ-Al2O3 for the transesterification of palm (refined and crude) and rapeseed oils with methanol. The reaction was carried out at the range of 150–250°C using methanol/oil molar ratio from 7 to 28 and 10wt.% of catalyst. For La2O3, methyl esters yield of 97.1% was obtained for rapeseed oil, which contains 0.75wt.% of free fatty acids, using methanol/oil molar ratio of 28 at 200°C. The excellent performance of La2O3 catalyst was attributed to its higher basicity compared to the other rare earth oxides. On the other hand, for La2O3/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, the catalytic performance was always lower than that of bulk oxide, reaching a maximum yield of 60% for rapeseed oil using a catalyst containing 20% of La2O3 supported on γ-Al2O3. This result was poorer than those obtained by the catalysts studied in this work at the same temperature, but in the presence of a larger excess of methanol. Lower yields (12%) were reported for the transesterification of J. curcas oil with methanol at 65°C using 5wt.% of La2O3/Al2O3 catalyst and methanol/oil molar ratio equal to 6 for 3h [4]. By comparing the results of Endalew et al. [4] with those of the present study and of Russbueldt and Hoelderich [18], it can be suggested that high reaction temperature and a reasonable excess of methanol seem to be fundamental to the performance of Al, La-based catalysts. 3.2.3 Comparison between Mg,La- and Al,La-catalysts Mg,La- and Al,La-catalysts with different chemical compositions were synthesized using (NH4)2CO3/NH4OH as precipitating agent and calcined at 450°C. The physicochemical properties indicated that chemical composition influenced the crystalline phases and textural characteristics of the samples, and that the increase of La content led to a reduction in specific area and pore volume. Another important feature of these samples was the absence of basic species leaching into reaction medium. For Mg, La-samples, the investigation of basic properties indicated that basic site density decreases as La content increases. Mg/La 9:1 sample showed the highest biodiesel yield (FAME=81%) at 200°C. The best catalytic performance of this sample is consistent with the higher basic sites density measured by the techniques used in this study (titration using Hammett indicators, CO2-TPD and 2-propanol transformation) and also with the highest specific area observed for this sample. For Al,La-samples, Al/La 9:1 catalyst showed the best catalytic performance (FAME yield=79 %) at 200°C. The sample with the highest catalytic activity (Al/La 9:1) also presented the highest concentration of basic sites and specific area, but it was not possible to correlate the basicity measures and textural properties of the other samples of this series with the catalytic performance. These two series of catalysts were active for the transesterification of soybean oil and methanol. At 200°C, the catalytic performance of all samples is similar; however, at 130°C, Mg/La 9:1 and 1:1 produced higher yields (60 and 66%, respectively) than the corresponding Al/La samples. 3.3 The use of acid feedstock for biodiesel production The catalysts of the two series studied (Mg/La and Al/La) that showed the best catalytic performance were selected to study the influence of the presence of free fatty acids in the vegetable oil used to produce biodiesel. Catalytic tests were carried out in the presence of an acid soybean oil (10wt.% of oleic acid) at 130 and 200°C for 4h using a methanol/acid soybean oil molar ratio of 45 and 5wt.% of catalyst concentration. As can be seen in Table 4 , which shows the conversion of oleic acid in the acid feedstock, the studied catalysts were able to promote the esterification of free fatty acid at both studied temperatures. As noted for the transesterification of soybean oil, the esterification of oleic acid was favored by the increase of reaction temperature and a levelling-off effect was observed. Al/La 9:1 sample is a better catalyst for oleic acid esterification at 130°C. Table 4 shows the residual content of oleic acid in obtained biodiesel expressed in mg of KOH per gram of biodiesel in order to compare the content of free fatty acid with the specification of commercial biodiesel. Although the reduction of oleic acid content has been significantly at high reaction temperature, the values are still high when compared to the specification of commercial biodiesel (0.5mg KOH/g biodiesel). In Fig. 14 , it is possible to compare FAME yields obtained with refined oil (RO) and model acid oil for Mg/La 9:1 and Al/La 9:1 catalysts. The bars corresponding to methyl esters yields show, in the case of acid oil, the contribution of the transesterification of soybean oil (TC) and the esterification of oleic acid (EC) to total yield (Appendix A in Supplementary data). For acid oil, the increase of reaction temperature increased total methyl esters yield, as already observed for the reaction using refined oil. In the case of Mg/La 9:1 catalyst, it was noted that, at 130 and 200°C, the presence of free fatty acids in the feedstock slightly affected FAME yield. However, it has been observed, particularly at 200°C, a reduction of oil transesterification contribution in ester formation that was balanced by the esterification of oleic acid. This reduction can be associated to the deactivation of the sites responsible for transesterification reaction. With respect to Al/La 9:1 catalyst, at both studied reaction temperatures, the reduction in the contribution of oil transesterification to ester formation was balanced by the esterification of oleic acid (Fig. 14). As a result, no significant differences with respect to total FAME yield for refined oil and acid oil were noticed. As can be seen in Fig. 14, the sites responsible for transesterification reaction deactivated at 130 and 200°C in the presence of oleic acid. For both catalysts this deactivation can be related to the adsorption of oleic acid on the sites active for transesterification reactions. Comparing the catalytic performance of Mg/La 9:1 and Al/La 9:1 samples at 130°C, it can be noticed that Mg/La 9:1 sample is a better catalyst for transesterification reaction, while Al/La 9:1 sample is more efficient for esterification reaction than Mg/La 9:1 sample (Table 4). Therefore, it can be inferred that Mg, La-catalysts are suitable to the transesterification of soybean oil with methanol. The presence of Mg is crucial for the catalytic behavior, as the catalyst with lower Mg content (Mg/La 1:9) presents low FAME yield. It is also important to highlight that specific area and basic site density fail to explain the better catalytic performance of Mg, La-catalysts in comparison with Al, La ones, since these properties are lower for the former catalysts. Thus, it seems that super basic sites clearly observed in TPD-CO2 profiles of Mg/La 9:1 and 1:1 samples play an important role in soybean oil transesterification with methanol. Mg/La 9:1 and Al/La 9:1 samples have sites capable of catalyzing transesterification and esterification reactions, and the results can be considered promising regarding their use in transesterification of acid oils. However, experimental conditions can be adjusted to achieve conversion and residual acidity levels required by biodiesel standard specifications. 4 Conclusion The use of (NH4)2CO3/NH4OH solution as precipitating agent and the precursor calcination at 450°C were the best synthesis conditions, because the sample prepared using this method showed good catalytic, basic and textural properties and no leaching of basic species into reaction medium. The catalytic activity of Mg,La-catalysts can be correlated with basic site density measured by different techniques (titration with Hammett indicators, TPD-CO2, 2-propanol transformation) and also with specific area. However, this correlation was not observed for Al,La-catalysts. At 130°C, Mg, La-catalysts showed higher biodiesel yield than Al,La-catalysts. This result was not consistent with basic site density and specific area. In general, the difficulty to establish a relationship between catalytic activity and basic properties in this work, confirm that the basicity characterization is still a challenging problem due to the difficulty in selecting an appropriate technique (based on the use of probe molecules or model reactions) that can be able to properly represent the catalytic mechanism involved in the studied reaction. Regarding the production of biodiesel from acid oils, Al, La-catalysts showed a better esterification activity than Mg, La-catalysts, but the sites responsible for transesterification reaction of the former catalysts were deactivated by the presence of free fatty acid. coredata.dc:description: The growing concern for environmental preservation combined with the possibility of depletion of energy obtained from fossil fuels has driven industry to develop alternative fuels from renewable resources and environmentally non-aggressive processes. Biodiesel is an important alternative fuel whose properties are similar to those of petrodiesel. Catalysts containing Mg/La (Mg/La molar ratio=9:1) were prepared by coprecipitation using three methods that differed according to precipitating agent, and calcination temperature. The catalyst prepared with (NH4)2CO3/NH4OH as precipitating agent and calcined at 450°C presented the best physicochemical and catalytic properties. Catalysts based on Mg/Al and Al/La with different chemical compositions were synthesized under the selected conditions. The catalytic behavior of these materials for transesterification of soybean oil with methanol was investigated and the catalysts with M/La molar ratio equal to 9:1 (M=Mg or Al) showed the best catalytic performance. Catalytic tests were also carried out in the presence of acid soybean oil. It was verified that the catalysts used have sites capable of catalyzing esterification and transesterification reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Preparation, basic properties and catalytic activity of Mg/La and Al/La catalysts for biodiesel production from refined and acid soybean oil
coredata.prism:issueName: Contributions of Homogeneous and Heterogeneous Catalysis in Biorefining: Special Issue in Honor of Prof. Ulf Schuchardt
